rows.title: Fun with Food

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You’ve unlocked a new play activity: Fun with Food! Today, we’ll explore how cooking can help your child learn maths while bonding together.
Start by inviting your child to help prepare a snack, like making a pizza or a colourful fruit salad. As you gather the ingredients, ask them to count: 'How many grapes do we have?' This builds maths skills and encourages teamwork.
Next, involve them in addition and subtraction: 'We need five grapes, if we have three, how many more do we need?' This makes learning fun!
Let’s make it playful! Ask, 'Which is bigger: the grape or the apple?' This reinforces comparison skills.
Consider planning a weekly cooking night. Cooking strengthens your relationship and builds your child’s confidence. Enjoy your cooking adventure together!

rows.title: Object Sorting Adventure

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Object Sorting Adventure!
Help your little one discover the joy of learning by sorting objects and things!
By grouping items like a bear as an animal or a mango as a fruit, they’ll start to understand how different things fit together.
Grab a picture book and ask, 'Can you find all the animals?' and then once they have done this you can ask if they can find all of the animals who can swim or jump. It’s an easy way to begin!
At home, find safe objects and let them sort them by colour, size, or type—plastic cups and plates are perfect for this! Want to make it more interesting? Try sorting pots and pans by size: Can they fit the small pans into the larger ones?
And remember, you can play this game anywhere! Just look around and ask them to find things from a category you name. Let the learning begin!"

attribution.eng: Adapted from [Brain building through play by Harvard University](https://developingchild.harvard.edu/resources/brainbuildingthroughplay/)

rows.title: Pattern Discovery

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Pattern Discovery!
Did you know that patterns are all around us? From the natural world to things we use every day, recognizing patterns helps set the stage for future maths skills.
Your child will start by noticing patterns, and before long, they’ll be copying, extending, and creating their own!
Explore patterns together—whether it's the rows of palm trees outside or the design on their clothes. At home, try making patterns with simple items like colourful blocks, rocks, or feathers.
Draw a pattern using simple shapes and ask your child questions like: “What comes next?’” or “Can you create your own pattern?” Remember to encourage and celebrate their curiosity as they explore the world of patterns!

rows.title: Guess the emotion!

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Guess the Emotion!
Let’s have some fun expressing feelings! Ask your child, “What does it look like when we’re happy, angry, or surprised?” Then, take turns acting out different emotions and guessing what the other person is feeling.
This isn’t just a game—it’s a chance for your child to learn how to recognize emotions in others. By understanding facial expressions, they’ll strengthen their connections with others and develop empathy.
So, get ready to act out some emotions and enjoy this special play activity together!

attribution.eng: I am Safe, Loved, and Learning by Save the Children

rows.title: Photo Puzzle

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Photo Puzzle!
Get ready to turn a photo into a fun jigsaw puzzle that boosts memory and direction skills!

You’ll need scissors, copies of family photos, and optionally, cardboard and glue to make the puzzle more durable.
First, take a copy of your photo and cut it into at least three pieces. Older children can try cutting up the pieces for younger children if they already know how to use scissors safely.
If the paper is thin, you can glue it to some cardboard to make it feel more like a real puzzle. Remember to let the glue dry before you start cutting!
Now, flip the pieces face down so you can’t see the picture.
Your challenge? Rebuild the photo together by turning over one piece at a time and putting it back together.
If your child needs a little help, ask guiding questions like, 'Where do you think this piece goes?'
It’s a quick and fun way to strengthen memory and problem-solving skills—plus, it’s a great reason to look at some photos together!

rows.title: Animal Acting

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Act Like an Animal!
Get ready to roar like a lion or hop like a kangaroo! This fun and active game helps kids develop physical skills while also supporting speech and language development.
To start, you’ll need a few simple things: small toy animals or pictures of animals, and a box or container to hold them.
Each player picks an animal from the container. Then, take turns acting out the animal—can you mimic its sounds and movements? Roar, jump, crawl, or fly just like the animal you picked!
For older kids, turn it into a fun guessing game—see if others can guess which animal you’re pretending to be!
It’s a great way to get moving, learn, and have fun together!

rows.title: Cotton Colours

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Cotton Colours. 
Let’s get creative and colourful while building motor skills and patience.
First, gather your materials: scissors, glue, food colouring, small bowls, cotton balls, dropper, and an egg carton.
Start by mixing food colouring and water. Make lots of different colours in small bowls. 
Now, get the cotton balls out. Arrange the cotton balls into the shape of a rainbow and use the droppers to paint each colour, from top to bottom. 
Now you can try a new game! Take your egg carton, make small holes in each egg space—just big enough to push a cotton ball through.
Finally, push your coloured cotton balls through the holes to make different colourful patterns. It’s a playful way to explore colours and have some hands-on fun!

rows.title: Follow the leader

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Follow the Leader!
This exciting imitation game is all about movement, memory, and fun! Start by choosing someone to be the leader—an adult is a great way to kick things off. The other players line up behind the leader, ready to follow along.
The leader can move in any way they like—run, jump, crawl, or even tiptoe! The rest of the players must copy every move. The leader can change movements at any time, keeping everyone in suspense!
Take turns being the leader, and remember, you can play with just two people or as many as you want! It’s a fantastic way to build working memory, attention, and self-control while having fun together!

attribution.eng: Adapted from [Brain building through play by Harvard University](https://developingchild.harvard.edu/resources/brainbuildingthroughplay/)

rows.title: Book Sharing Time

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Book Sharing Time!
Reading together is not only a fun, playful way to spend quality time but also a fantastic way to help your child learn and grow.
Choose a time when you won’t be disturbed, and try to minimise distractions—turn off the TV, put away mobile phones, and create a calm space. If your child wants to pick the book, great! If not, you can choose one for them.
As you read, sit close together and follow their lead. Point to things in the book, name objects, and repeat words to help them engage with what interests them. Link the story to their life—use words about emotions and talk about how the characters might be feeling.
If you can, start a regular reading routine when your child isn’t too tired or hungry. This habit can become a cherished time that supports their learning and prepares them for school success.
Reading together is one of the most valuable ways to help your child learn, build curiosity, and bond over stories!

rows.title: String and create

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: String and create!
This activity is a great way for your child to explore colours, shapes, and build their fine motor skills. 
Here’s what you can do: set out some colourful beads where your child can play freely. Encourage them to string the beads, guiding them to sort by colour or shape if they’d like. Older kids may want to join in and try creating different patterns or spelling words out with alphabet beads.
As they string the beads, count together how many they’ve added. Celebrate their hard work by congratulating them on the beautiful misbah they’ve created! Remember, adult supervision is important when little kids are handling beads. Make sure the beads are large in size and that children don’t put them in their mouths as this is a choking hazard!
What to look for: Notice how your child is learning about different colours and how they’re gaining better control of their hands, which helps develop dexterity.
It’s a simple, engaging activity that combines creativity, learning, and skill-building, all while having a great time!

attribution.eng: Adapted from [Early Childhood Development Kit by UNICEF](https://www.unicef.org/supply/early-childhood-development-ecd-kit)

rows.title: Freeze Dance

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Freeze Dance!
Get ready to dance and freeze with this exciting activity that toddlers love! Play some music and let your child dance or move however they like. When the music stops, tell them to freeze – to not move at all! – in place. This fun game is great for building listening skills and self-control as they practise stopping and starting.
It’s also a wonderful way to prepare for school, where they’ll need to follow directions. So, turn up the music and enjoy the dancing – and the freezing!

attribution.eng: Adapted from [Brain building through play by Harvard University](https://developingchild.harvard.edu/resources/brainbuildingthroughplay/)

rows.title: Shadow Play

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Shadow Play!
Step into a world of imagination and light with this exciting activity! In a darkened room, grab a flashlight and shine it at your hand, casting fun shadows onto the wall. Wave at your child and create silly shapes with your fingers—maybe a bunny, a bird, or whatever your imagination dreams up! Watch as their curiosity grows, and invite them to try waving their shadow hand back.
Encourage your little one to take a turn with the flashlight, giving them the thrill of seeing how light can create different shapes and movements on the wall. Older children might want to join in the fun and make a shadow animal of their own! This hands-on experience helps them understand cause and effect, and boosts their creativity as they experiment with their own shadow creations.
It's a delightful, interactive way to explore movement and creativity, all while strengthening their focus and sense of wonder!

rows.title: Mini Obstacle Race

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Mini Obstacle Race!
Get ready to set up an exciting adventure right in your home! Using soft play equipment, pillows, chairs, and hula hoops or skipping ropes, create a fun and safe obstacle race for your toddler to explore. The goal? For your little one to navigate the course by crawling, jumping, and climbing over, under, and through the obstacles.
As they tackle each challenge, they’ll be developing important gross motor skills like coordination, balance, and strength. Not only will this activity get them moving, but it will also boost their confidence as they conquer each part of the race.
It’s an easy, playful way to promote physical development while having a great time together! Let the obstacle adventure begin!

rows.title: Letter Hunt

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Letter Hunt!
Turn your next trip to the store into a learning adventure! As you shop, pick a letter and talk about the items on your list that start with that letter. Ask your child to find other things in the store that start with the same letter. This simple activity helps build your child’s letter recognition and vocabulary while keeping them engaged during the shopping trip. It’s a fun, interactive way to learn about letters and sounds in real-world situations, turning an ordinary task into an exciting educational game!

rows.title: Shape and Colour

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Shape and Colour!
Here’s what you’ll need: construction paper in different colours, crayons, markers, or paint.
What to do: Cut out various shapes from the colourful construction paper. Circles, squares, triangles, and more! As your toddler explores, talk about the different colours and let them sort the shapes into groups. You can also encourage them to trace each shape with crayons, markers, or even paint to add an extra layer of creativity.
What kids will learn: This activity is perfect for boosting colour recognition and fine motor skills. Your toddler will also learn about different shapes as they engage in hands-on play, combining creativity with learning in a fun, interactive way!

rows.title: Mystery Bag

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Mystery Bag!
This versatile game is perfect for engaging your toddler’s senses and building vocabulary. Simply place a variety of objects into a bag and ask your child to reach in, feel an item, and guess what it is before pulling it out. When they pull out the item, give them some descriptive vocabulary to describe what you see: Is it smooth or scary? Bumpy or bright? It’s a fun way to introduce new words and stimulate their sense of touch!
Benefits of this activity include expanding vocabulary, developing tactile senses, and practising grouping skills. It’s a wonderful way to mix fun with learning!

rows.title: Body Outline

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Body Outline!
This fun and interactive game helps your toddler learn about different parts of the body. Start by drawing their body outline on a large piece of paper. As you go, ask them to point to and name different body parts. For example, you can say, “Where’s your nose?” or “Can you point to your feet?” As they point, encourage them to name each part. You can also add stickers or colour in the outline to make it more creative and engaging!
The benefits of this activity include improving body awareness, expanding vocabulary, and developing fine motor skills.

rows.title: Paper Ball Game

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: The Paper Ball Game!
Get ready to test your child’s aim and decision-making skills with this simple yet exciting game. Using paper balls, you'll have fun while sharpening physical coordination.
Here’s what you’ll need: paper (to scrunch up into balls), and crayons.
Start by colouring each piece of paper so that it is a unique colour. Make sure you can tell the balls apart. Now scrunch up the paper until you have a paper ball.
Next, make a goal. You can use markings that already exist, or a clear table surface. Now you’re ready to play! Take turns tossing your ball towards the goal. Whoever scores or lands closest to the goal wins the round!
This fun and engaging game is perfect for boosting your child’s physical coordination and decision-making skills while keeping them entertained. Let the friendly competition begin!

rows.title: Leader Says

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Leader Says!
This classic game is a great way to help your child build listening skills, focus on following directions, and have fun at the same time! Here’s how you can play together:
One of you will take the role of the Leader, giving commands to the other. But there’s a fun twist! Your child should only follow the command if it starts with “Leader says”. For example, if you say, “Leader says jump", they should jump. But if you just say “Jump” without the “Leader says” part, they shouldn’t move!
Encourage your child to listen carefully and respond only when they hear “Leader says". If they follow a command without it, gently remind them to pay attention and keep going for the next round.
Now it’s time to switch roles! Let your child be Leader and give you the commands. 
This playful activity is a wonderful way to practise listening, self-control, and quick thinking—perfect for getting your child engaged while learning important skills. Enjoy the fun of Leader Says together!

rows.title: Superhero Costume Raffle

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Superhero Costume Raffle!
Get ready to transform into superheroes with this fun and imaginative dressing-up game! It’s a fantastic way to encourage creative thinking, flexible language skills, and playful bonding.
Here’s what you’ll need: Two items of clothing for each person playing, and a pillowcase or bag to hold them.
Start by placing all the clothes in the pillowcase. Hand the pillowcase to the smallest player first. Make sure their eyes are shut, then let them pull out one item of clothing.
Next, pass the case around until everyone gets two items of clothing. The fun begins as everyone imagines what superpower each piece of clothing gives them. Maybe a scarf makes you fly, or a hat gives you super speed—it’s totally up to your imagination!
Now it’s time to play! All the heroes can now put on their clothes to activate their superpowers! Join forces and save the world with your unique superhero abilities. Let the superhero adventure begin!

Now it’s time to play! All the heroes can now put on their clothes to activate their superpowers! Join forces and save the world with your unique superhero abilities. Let the superhero adventure begin!

rows.title: What We See

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: What We See!
Get ready to turn your home into a scavenger hunt with this fun and interactive spelling game. It’s a fantastic way to boost physical, creative, and cognitive skills while exploring your surroundings.
Here’s what you’ll need: paper, pens, and safe objects from around the house.
Start by writing down each letter of the alphabet—one letter per piece of paper. Once you've finished, place the papers face down so you can’t see the letters.
Now, turn over one piece of paper to reveal a letter. The challenge? Find objects around your house that begin with that letter! Once you've found an item, place it next to the letter on the paper.
Keep the hunt going! Flip over the next letter and search for another object. Continue until you’ve gone through all the letters. After all that hunting, take a well-earned break!
This activity is perfect for blending learning with active play, while giving your little ones a fun way to practise their alphabet and creativity!

rows.title: Treasure Hunt

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Treasure Hunt!
Ready to embark on a thrilling hunt for hidden treasure? This fun-filled game is perfect for challenging problem-solving and communication skills while keeping everyone engaged with exciting clues!
Here’s what you’ll need: something easy to hide, like toys or balls, and if you want to take it up a notch, use paper and crayons to create your very own treasure map.
Start by choosing one player to hide an object, making sure no one else sees where it’s hidden. The player who hid the object will now give clues to help the others find it. Clues can be about what's in front of, behind, or above the hidden treasure. 
Need help? When the person searching is getting close to where the object is hidden, the hider can say “getting warm!” or “hot!”, and when the searcher is going in the wrong direction, the hider can say “getting colder…”.
Take turns hiding objects and giving clues—it’s fun for everyone to get involved!
For an extra challenge, hide multiple objects around the house and create a treasure map or poster showing pictures of the hidden items. You can even include a fun reward for those who find all the treasures!
It’s the perfect way to combine problem-solving with a thrilling treasure hunt adventure!

rows.title: Shine a light

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Shine A Light!
Get ready to let your creativity shine with shadow drawing! This activity is a fun and imaginative way to boost creativity and flexible thinking while exploring shadows and light.
Here’s what you’ll need: pens, paper, and a flashlight.
Start by having your child choose an object that they would like to draw—it could be anything from around the house, like a cup or a favourite toy. 

Have them place the object upright on a blank sheet of paper.
Hold the flashlight behind the object so the shadow appears on the paper. You can take turns holding the flashlight, or rest it on something sturdy to keep your hands free for drawing.
Now, guide your child so they can trace the shadow’s outline on the paper. Once they have finished drawing the shape, it’s time to get creative! Colour and decorate the shadow together to add your own artistic touch.
For extra fun, make up a story about the shadow object together as you decorate. What is it doing today? Use your imagination as you create and explore the world of shadows!

rows.title: Building Blocks Dictionary

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Building Blocks Dictionary!
Get ready to put your building skills and creativity to the test with this fun and challenging game! Building Blocks dictionary is perfect for developing emotional and thinking skills while having fun with building Building Blocks bricks.
Here’s what you’ll need: a pile of building blocks, paper, pens, and scissors.
Start by having an adult or older child cut the paper into small, card-sized pieces. On each card, write and/or draw a word that everyone will understand, like "dog", "house", or "tree". Kids will have some great ideas about what to put into the pile!
Place the pile of building blocks in the centre of the table and the word cards face down in a stack.
Team up younger players with older players and take turns picking a word card. The player who picks the card must use the building blocks to build something that represents the word while the others try to guess what it is! Decide as a group how long each player has to build their creation.
The person building can make anything they like to represent the word—just no letters or numbers allowed! Other players can ask yes-or-no questions to help them guess, but that’s all the builder can say.
Building Blocks Dictionary is a fantastic way to inspire creativity, teamwork, and problem-solving—all while enjoying a fun game together!

rows.title: Colour Hunt

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Colour Hunt!
Get ready for a colourful adventure that will challenge your thinking and focus. In this exciting game, you’ll be hunting for objects in matching colours while having lots of fun.
Here’s what you’ll need: building blocks or any other objects in a variety of different colours (like crayons or markers).
Start by placing all the coloured blocks in a bag. Each participant picks one block from the bag to get started.
Now, the challenge begins! Each player must find three other objects around the house that are the same colour as their block. Search everywhere for the perfect matches!
When a player finds an object that matches the colour of their block, they place the block next to it and shout "match!"
Once a player has found three matching objects, they can head back to the bag, choose another block, and start the hunt all over again!
Colour Hunt is a fantastic way to boost focus, encourage problem-solving, and keep everyone moving and engaged. Let the colourful treasure hunt begin!

rows.title: I Spy

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: I Spy!
This classic game is a fun and interactive way to help your child learn about letters and words while keeping them engaged.
To start, choose an object around you—something your child knows the name of, like a “ball". Don’t tell them what it is just yet!
Now, say the magic words: “I spy with my little eye, something beginning with...” and say the first letter of the word—in this case, “B” for “ball".
Encourage your child to look around and guess what the object might be. When they guess correctly, give them praise and switch roles! If they’re having trouble, offer clues like, “It’s round” or “It’s black and white".
Keep the game going with new objects and different letters. This playful activity is a fantastic way to build your child’s understanding of letters and sounds, which will help them on their reading journey at home and in school.

attribution.eng: Adapted from [Brain building through play by Harvard University](https://developingchild.harvard.edu/resources/brainbuildingthroughplay/)

rows.title: Games with Pictures

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Games with Pictures!
This activity helps spark creativity and language skills by making up stories from pictures.
Start by showing your child a picture, and then say, “We are going to make up a story about this picture. I’ll start.” For example, you might say, “This little girl looks very excited today. Why do you think she’s excited?”
Encourage your child to think about the picture and add their ideas. You could say, “She’s holding her bag and has a big smile. Where do you think she’s going?”
Let the story unfold as you both take turns adding details. This activity boosts your child's imagination, builds their vocabulary, and helps them practise storytelling. The more pictures you explore, the more creative your stories will become!

rows.title: Playtime with books

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Playtime with Books. 
Let’s have some fun reading together and help your child learn while spending quality time! Start by choosing a moment when you won’t be interrupted. Turn off the TV, put away mobile phones, and create a cosy space for your reading adventure.
If your child wants to pick a book, great! If not, you can choose one for them. Sit close together and follow their lead—point to pictures, name objects, and repeat words they’re curious about.
If the book has letters or numbers, ask your child to recognize them and help them read simple words. Don’t forget to link the story to your child’s life. Talk about emotions in the book and ask, “How do you think the character feels?”
This activity is more than just reading—it’s a way to build literacy, foster a love for books, and help your child grow. Try to make reading part of your daily routine when your child is relaxed and ready to enjoy the moment.
So, cuddle up, dive into a story, and let the magic of reading bring you closer while helping your child learn and succeed!

rows.title: Opposites Game

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Opposites Game!
This fun game will help your child sharpen their thinking and keep them engaged with matching and sorting in a whole new way!
Here’s how to get started:
Create cards by drawing a grid on a piece of paper. You and your child can then search through magazines, cut out pictures, and glue them into the grid spaces. You’ll need small objects like buttons to use as markers.
Instead of matching pictures that are called out, your child will mark the opposite! For example, if you say “daytime”, they’ll mark a space with a picture of “nighttime”. If you call out “hot”, they’ll look for a picture that represents “cold”. Remember to ensure you call out words that have corresponding opposites on your child’s card.
This activity is great for boosting your child’s understanding of opposites while keeping things fun and challenging.
So, gather your materials, call out those opposites, and enjoy the excitement of playing Opposites Game together!

attribution.eng: Adapted from [Brain building through play by Harvard University](https://developingchild.harvard.edu/resources/brainbuildingthroughplay/)

rows.title: Blanket Forts

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Building a Blanket Fort!
Let’s dive into creating your very own cosy hideaway! First, gather everything you’ll need—blankets, pillows, chairs, and maybe even a table. If you want to add a little magic, grab a flashlight to light up your fort.
Now, it’s time to build. Start by setting up two chairs facing each other, or use a table as the main structure of your fort. Drape the blankets over the chairs or table to create a roof. Don’t forget to secure them—use clips or heavy books to hold everything in place so your fort stays strong!
Next, make it extra comfy. Fill the inside with pillows, cushions, and maybe even a soft rug. This will be your cosy corner to relax, read, or play together.
Once your fort is built, add some fun touches. String up lights, bring in your favourite toys or books, and decorate the space however you like. You could even make a “welcome” sign to make it feel like your very own special house!
Now, crawl inside and enjoy your new fort! This is your cosy, creative space for reading stories, playing games, or just spending some quiet time together.
Building a blanket fort is more than just a fun activity—it’s a chance to spark creativity, solve problems, and share special moments together. So, grab those blankets and start building your adventure today!

rows.title: Tricky Tower

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Tricky Tower!
Get ready for an exciting activity that will test your child’s ability to take risks, work as a team, and think creatively—all while having fun and developing fine motor skills.
Here’s how to play: 
Start by giving each child building blocks or building blocks. Ask them to build a tower by stacking the blocks vertically, using just one hand. This challenge helps build focus and concentration as they balance the blocks carefully.
Next, pair up the children and challenge them to create the tallest tower in the group—again, using only one hand. Working together, they’ll realise how tricky it can be to keep the tower from falling over, especially as they try to make it taller. Encourage them to talk about their strategy and work as a team.
Finally, make the game even more challenging! Ask the teams to build the tallest tower they can in just two minutes, but this time, using their non-dominant hand. They’ll have to balance the desire for height with the risk of the tower collapsing.
This isn’t just about building—it’s about problem-solving, persistence, and teamwork. Tricky Tower is a fantastic way to help your child develop important skills while having fun with friends or family.
So, grab those blocks and get ready for some tower-building fun!

rows.title: Flip the blanket

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Flip the Blanket!
Can you and your child flip a blanket while standing on it? This fun and challenging game will get everyone thinking creatively and working as a team to solve the problem.
Here’s how to play:
Start by laying a blanket or large piece of cloth flat on the ground. Have all the players stand on the blanket—make sure no one steps off!
Now, the challenge begins. The players must work together to flip the blanket over without stepping off or touching the ground. Experiment with different ideas, try new strategies, and see what works best!
If anyone touches the ground, no worries—just start over and give it another try.
While you are playing, talk about the problem-solving you are doing. Ask the players what ideas they are trying and why, how they are working together, and what is working and what is not. Discuss how they came up with solutions as a team.
Flip the Blanket is a fantastic way to encourage teamwork, creative thinking,problem solving, and perseverance—all while having a great time together!

rows.title: Can you catch it?

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Can You Catch It?
Let’s see if you can follow instructions while catching a ball! This fun and challenging game will train your concentration and reflexes—and it’s trickier than it looks. Plus, you can adjust the rules to make it perfect for every age!
Here’s how to play:
Start by standing about three metres apart and gently toss a ball or bean bag to each other. After a few easy throws, it’s time to introduce the rules!
When the thrower shouts ‘one’, the catcher has to catch the ball with their right hand and put their left foot out. If the thrower shouts ‘two’, the catcher catches with their left hand and puts their right foot out.
Once you’re confident, add some extra rules! If the thrower shouts ‘three’, the catcher has to catch with their right hand and put their right foot out. And if the thrower shouts ‘four’, the catcher catches with their left hand and puts their left foot out.
For the game to work, make sure the number is called before you throw the ball, so the catcher has time to react!
This activity is a great way to improve coordination, concentration, and quick thinking—all while having fun! So, grab a ball and start tossing with these new rules to test your skills!

rows.title: Unseen Guesses

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Unseen Guesses!
This activity is all about teamwork, communication, and overcoming frustration through both verbal and non-verbal cues. It’s a fun way for children to practise effective communication while working towards a common goal.
Here’s how to play:
Start by organising the group into teams of three. Each person takes on a role: speaker, challenger, and guesser. The speaker and guesser are blindfolded and sit next to each other.
Next, the challenger selects an object (like a toy, or cushion) and hands it to the speaker. The speaker feels the object but isn’t allowed to name it. Instead, they describe what it feels like—without giving away the name!
The guesser’s job is to figure out what the object is based on the speaker’s description. The guesser can ask questions, but the speaker can only answer with "yes" or "no".
After each round, swap roles and play again, giving everyone a chance to be the speaker, challenger, and guesser.
This game is not only fun but also helps children develop strong communication skills and teaches them how to work together to achieve a goal. Enjoy working through the challenge of Unseen Guesses!

rows.title: Things that make me happy

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Things That Make Me Happy!
Let’s take some time to appreciate the little things that make us feel happy every day. This fun activity will boost your creativity, improve emotional skills, and bring a smile to your face by focusing on positivity.
Here’s how to play:
Start by talking about the things that made you happy today. It could be anything—a friend, a favourite pet, a book, or even a game that made you smile.
Next, choose at least three things that represent what makes you happy and place them in a special container or box. If you have more than three, go ahead and add them too.
If the things that make you happy are too big to fit in the box, or if you can’t find something to represent them, get creative! Use craft materials or building blocks to draw or build models. You could create a little model of your pet or draw a picture of your favourite book!
Once everything is in the box, discuss what you and your child chose. Ask them why these things make them happy. It’s a great way to get them talking about positive emotions.
You can play this game as often as you like—even daily! Doing this before bed can help your child stay motivated, happy, and calm, especially during tough times.
So, gather those happy things and create a special box full of joy!

rows.title: Nature Game

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Nature Game!
Let’s have some fun exploring the world around you with a nature-themed game! This activity helps boost concentration and flexible thinking, and you can play it anywhere—at the beach, in your house garden, or even on a walk.
Here’s how to play:
First, draw a grid of 3 by 3 on a piece of paper and fill the spaces with things you might find in nature—like a tree, flower, rock, bird, or cloud.
Now, it’s time to explore! Head outside and start searching for the items on your card. Each time you find something, mark it off.
You decide when you win! Maybe it’s when you’ve marked off a whole line, or perhaps when you’ve found everything on your card. It’s completely up to you!
Nature Game is a great way to explore the outdoors, stay active, and have fun while learning more about the world around you. So, get outside and start your nature hunt!

rows.title: Raise the bottles

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Raise The Bottles!
Get ready to have some outdoor fun while testing your teamwork and coordination in this fast-paced bottle game!
Here’s how to play: Start by dividing the players into two teams. Team A should have at least two people, while team B can be just one person.
Next, set up three plastic bottles in a line with plenty of space between them. You can add more bottles later for extra challenge!
Mark two lines on either side of the bottles, where team A will stand. It’s up to you how far these lines should be from the bottles—make it challenging, but fair!
Now, it’s game time! Team A stands behind their lines and tries to knock the bottles over using a soft ball, while Team B rushes to stand the bottles back up as quickly as possible.
Before you begin, decide how long each game will last—about three minutes is a good starting point.
If Team A manages to knock all the bottles down at the same time during those three minutes, they win! If Team B successfully keeps the bottles standing, they are the winners.
So, grab some bottles, a ball, and some friends, and get moving with this exciting outdoor challenge!

rows.title: Baking Time

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Baking Time!
Baking isn’t just about creating something delicious—it’s a fun and exciting way to learn new skills while exploring creativity. From mixing to decorating, your young chef will feel a sense of pride and accomplishment as they bring their tasty creations to life!
Here’s how to get started:
Pick a simple recipe, like cupcakes or chocolate chip cookies. Let your child jump in with all the steps—mixing ingredients, whisking the batter, and stirring everything together. If you are making cookies, invite your child to make shapes with the dough. Don’t be afraid to get messy!
Once your treats are in the oven, the fun continues with cleaning up the mess! 
Once your goodies are out of the oven, let your children take over again to decorate their masterpieces with frosting, sprinkles, or whatever inspires them.
Finally, enjoy the sweet results together! Not only will you have a yummy treat, but you’ll also have shared a special bonding moment while developing important skills like patience, focus, and creativity.
So, grab your chef hats and aprons, and let the baking fun begin!

rows.title: Secret Handshake

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Creating a Secret Handshake!
Let’s make a special, fun, and unique handshake that only you and your child share. This activity is a fantastic way to bond while encouraging creativity, teamwork, and playfulness!
Here’s how to get started:
First, sit down together and talk about the kind of handshake you want. Should it be quick and silly, or cool and complicated? It’s totally up to you! You can start by choosing a few simple moves like clapping patterns, high fives, fist bumps, or snapping fingers.
Next, practice adding different steps. Maybe a spin, a shoulder tap, or even a fun dance move! Keep practising until the two of you have your secret handshake down perfectly. And remember, the more creative and playful, the better!
Once you’ve mastered your moves, make your secret handshake a part of your routine! Use it as a fun greeting, before bedtime, or anytime you want to feel that special connection.
This isn’t just about having fun—it helps build your child’s confidence and teamwork skills while creating a special tradition you both can enjoy.
So, get creative, start practising, and let the secret handshake fun begin!

rows.title: Extreme balancing

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Extreme Balance!
Get ready to create an amazing, gravity-defying balance. This activity is perfect for sparking creativity while building your problem-solving and teamwork skills!
Here’s what you’ll need: Ruler, pencil, clothes hangers (plastic preferably), string, scissors, and then light objects to decorate your balance.
Here’s how to start:
First, experiment with balance. Place a ruler over a pencil to create a simple see-saw. Try balancing different objects on each end. How much weight does it take to tip the balance?
Next, challenge yourself further! Start with one hanger and slowly start hanging other hangers on either end of the first hanger. Now try hanging two more hangers from each hanger in the second tier. Remember to try to maintain balance between each of the hangers! See how many you can balance before they tumble down. It’s all about finding the right balance point.
Now that you’ve mastered balancing, it’s time to get creative! Think about the kind of balance you want to make. What materials will you use? What objects will hang from it? Gather materials like wire and thread, to form the structure of your balance.
For the fun part, choose the items to hang. You can use anything—folded paper shapes, drawings, small objects from around the house, or whatever inspires you.
Finally, start building and balancing! Experiment with different placements to keep everything steady and enjoy the process of creating a beautiful, gravity-defying piece of art.
This activity is a fun and creative way to learn about balance and teamwork while letting your imagination run wild. So, gather your materials and start your balancing adventure today!

rows.title: Olympic Challenge

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Olympic Challenge
Get ready to get your body moving and have fun while developing important social and thinking skills! This fun and active game will also help your child learn to manage their emotions while following instructions.
Here’s what you’ll need: paper, scissors, markers or pens, bottle caps.
Here’s how to play:
First, cut small, card-sized pieces of paper. On each card, write down or draw different age-appropriate, fun activities like "jump on one leg", "shake hands with all the players", or "do push-ups". Get creative with your tasks!
Next, place the cards face down on the floor. Do the same with bottle caps numbering them from 1 to 10. These numbers will tell you how many times to do the activity.
Now, it’s time to play! Take turns picking one card and one numbered bottle cap. The card will tell you what activity to do, and the number will tell you how many times. For example, you might have to do 8 push-ups or jump on one leg 5 times.
Keep taking turns and completing the tasks until all the activities are done, or play as long as you’d like!
This game is not only about having fun—it helps build physical coordination, teaches kids how to take turns, and develops their ability to follow instructions. So, gather your bottle caps and cards, and start the fun-filled challenge today!

rows.title: Create silly characters

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Create silly characters!
All you need to play this game is a piece of paper and everyone will need a pencil.
You are going to take turns drawing in this game, but it’s important that you can’t see what the other people are drawing, so set yourselves up in a way that you make sure this is possible.
Here’s how to play:
Decide who is going to draw first.
The first drawer should take the top 2–3 inches of the paper and draw the top (head, hat, hair) of a character. This can be as serious or silly as you want it to be.
Once the first part of the drawing is complete, fold the 2–3 inch column of artwork back, concealing what has been drawn but leaving two lines to demarcate where the next person who is drawing should pick up.
Pass the paper on to the next person, who, without seeing what has already been drawn, will contribute the next set of features to the character: The shoulders or torso. Fold the paper back to conceal the image and pass it on.
Repeat until someone has drawn the feet of the character and then open your drawing up to see the masterpiece you have collaboratively created!
This game builds creativity, nurtures imagination, and helps teach kids to collaborate!

rows.title: Guess the animal

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Guess the Animal!
Get ready to put your animal knowledge to the test in this exciting guessing game! Perfect for small or large groups, this game sharpens your reasoning skills and strengthens your memory while having fun.
Here’s how to play: One person secretly picks an animal—don’t let anyone else know which animal you’ve chosen! The other players take turns asking questions to figure it out. You might ask, “Is the animal a mammal?” or “Can it fly?” Keep going until someone guesses correctly. The person who gets it right goes next!
For added fun, younger kids can join by acting out the animal to give extra clues!
It’s a game everyone can enjoy—kids and adults alike—where learning and fun come together!

rows.title: Balloon Tennis

transcript.eng:
Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Balloon Tennis!
Gather materials such as balloons, paper plates, and paper straws. Take one paper plate and turn it over. 
Tape two straws to the back of the plate to make a sturdy racket. 
Repeat these steps to create more rackets for other players. Once your rackets are ready, blow up several balloons with your child for extra fun.
 Find an open area and start playing! Balloon Tennis is a fantastic way to keep kids active, improve their coordination, and most importantly, have fun together! Enjoy your game!
